utterances: (Reading) "We have made an immense failure here.
The system must have been far more at fault than anyone suspected.
It will have to be fundamentally changed.
I suppose we have underestimated the fact this country is really an inchoate mess of tribes, which can't as yet be reduced to any system.
The Turks didn't govern, and we have tried to govern and failed.
But Bell brought Faisal to Iraq and organized a referendum to validate his position as king.
Professor Sahdwin says no one else would have been able to accomplish such a feat.
(Through translator) The role played by Ms. Bell in establishing the modern Iraq was a great one.
And some people used to say about her, she was indeed the maker of kings.
Her influence, he says, extended beyond Iraq.
(Through translator) She contributed to making the Iraqi throne, that of King Faisal, along with Sir Percy Cox, she established the Kuwaiti Emirate.
She also helped found the East Jordan Emirate, what later came to be known as the Jordanian kingdom under the leadership of Prince Abdullah.
So what do you call a woman who did all that?
She loved Iraq and felt more at home in her house by the Tigris River than her family's country home in England.
And she wanted Iraq to succeed.
But her constitutional monarchy was deposed by a military coup after only 17 years.
Yet Iraq still bears her imprint.
She established the country's first museum and left it 50,000 British pounds in her will.
It's now closed to the public because of the ongoing violence.

After the fall of the regime, looters laid claim to many of the priceless artifacts collected in the museum, of which only a handful - including the sacred 5,200-year-old vase of Warka - had been retrieved.
Sitting in his old Baghdad house, historian Bahna Abulsov(ph) says Bell had many Iraqi friends, including Haji Naji(ph), a landowner with a famous garden of palm groves on the Tigris.
She used to arrive early in the morning before the sun arise - ride the horse from her house in (unintelligible) and go and have a breakfast with Haji Naji, and come back to her office around eight.
When she died, all of Baghdad turned out for her farewell.

At the arid cemetery in the Bato Sharjee(ph) neighborhood, the woman dubbed the uncrowned queen of Iraq lies in a simple stone tomb surrounded by the eroded epitaphs of British soldiers, diplomats, and Iraqi Christians.
Caretaker Ali Monsieur(ph) is a wizened, gaunt man in his 60s.
His family has tended the cemetery for generations.
Identical twin brother Dave, who was on the air in March of 2000.
That's exactly right.
She says she traveled to Syria four years ago from Alabama to join ISIS.
And she got married there to three ISIS fighters and had a son.
The New York Times reports that she used social media to call for attacks on Americans.
But now she says that she regrets joining ISIS and would like to return back to the United States.
Now, this comes as other countries are grappling with what to do with people coming home from the war in Syria.
The United Kingdom just revoked the citizenship of a woman who went to Syria.
Who is she?
What's her story?
So she's called Shamima Begum, and she's one of three girls that left when they were teenagers from Britain to Syria in 2015.
Begum was just 15 when she went to join ISIS.
They're known as the Bethnal Green girls after the parts of London that they came from.
So she's now also detained in this camp in Syria.
And she said in an interview with the BBC that she hopes Britain will understand that she made a very big mistake.
But the British home secretary has stripped her of her citizenship and is claiming that she is a threat to Britain.
So for the moment, these women, as we said, are in camps.
They are in Syria.
Just describe the situation there.
It's very difficult.
When we went there, it was harsh winter.
There weren't enough supplies, not enough tents to go around.
Some people were sleeping out in the open because of this.
They said that they couldn't get enough cooking pots, even.
So you have about 1,800 women - foreign women and children from countries all around the world - 46 countries at least.

Advocates of the families, for these women say, you know, there's a responsibility for countries to take these people back and that they would have to stand trial and face justice in their own countries because they say it could be a national security threat to actually leave them in these camps where they could be radicalized and, you know, left to languish with a very uncertain future.
NPR's Ruth Sherlock reporting there from Beirut.
Thank you, Ruth.
Thank you.
From the studios of NPR West, this is another all Alex DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Alex Cohen.
In a few minutes, a look at last night's four-man Republican debate.
First, tonight's Democratic presidential debate here in Los Angeles has just two participants - Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

And leading up to this moment, Senators Clinton and Obama have gone all over the country in anticipation of Super Tuesday, February 5th next week, when 22 states will hold Democratic nominating contests.
NPR's David Greene and Don Gonyea have been traveling with the two candidates and they join us now.
Let's start with David.
You're with Senator Clinton.
Tell us about her strategy for next week.
Well, Alex, I think you're going to be seeing a lot of Hillary Clinton in California.
That's a big state for her and it's not surprising that she's going to spend a couple of days focusing there.
It's delegate-rich and I think she wants to try and win as many as of the delegates that she possibly can to get those numbers up.
But it was interesting, Alex.

Yesterday Hillary Clinton spent a good amount of time in the evening in Georgia, which is one of the February 5th states, but it's a place that Obama appears to be doing very well, and you got the sense she might be doing some repair work with the African-American community.

She spoke to a national Baptist convention and there were a lot of people there, religious leaders who said that they are still wounds from South Carolina, feeling that the Clinton campaign and Bill Clinton made it about race and may have belittled Barack Obama's campaign.
Even people who support Hillary Clinton told me that they were a little uncomfortable with that.
Don, you know, the big news from Senator Obama's camp today is money, and a lot of it.
The campaign says that he raised $32 million in the month of January.
Now, give us context for that.
Well, that's really a remarkable number.
It is more money in one month than he has raised in any quarter previously.
So it does mean that after Iowa and after some of the earlier primaries and caucus contests, that he really has gotten momentum going in terms of fundraising ability.
You can feel something building there just as we see it at the events with the bigger and bigger crowds.
Now, here's what we don't know, though.
We don't know what the full quarterly numbers are.
We don't know what Hillary Clinton's numbers are for the same period.
She's had some successes in there as well.
So we've got to wait to really see what it means in comparison to the other candidates.
You were in Denver with him yesterday at a rally you've been talking to us about.
This rally in Denver - again, a state that Obama thinks he will carry next week - was just huge.
I mean, we've seen bigger and bigger rallies as he's really brought people in, kind of looking for some kind of emotional connection almost.
There were 10,000 people in the University of Denver's basketball arena.
There were another 9,000 who didn't get in and they had to funnel them - these long, long, long lines, into overflow rooms.
We did see from Senator Obama yesterday at that event in Denver some very pointed, tough talk toward Hillary Clinton, and directed at Bill Clinton.
He said do we need, after another presidency by a man named George Bush, to simply turn back the clock and build a bridge back to the 20th century.
That 20th century line, clearly kind of a mocking twist on that old Bill Clinton campaign slogan from his presidential runs, where he talked about building a bridge to the 21st century.
Ouch, I think.
David Greene, how is the Clinton campaign treating the issue of former President Bill Clinton, which had become something last week?
Hillary Clinton was asked very bluntly by a reporter, have you asked Bill Clinton to tone things down, tone down his campaign aggressiveness?
And the reporter said she's the only person who could probably do that.
Hillary Clinton did not answer the question exactly, but she did say, look, this is my campaign.
And now, how about speaking tonight?
A moment here on strategies for the debate.
Don Gonyea, let's start with you and Senator Obama.
Oh, my goodness.
That would have been back with Liane Hansen.
Must have been.
There is a sense from the Obama campaign that they don't want this to become kind of the shouting match that we saw in the last debate.

But there's also a sense that if there's just kind of the status quo, that probably helps Hillary Clinton, because she does seem to have a decent advantage going into Super Tuesday in so many states, especially with California and New York.
So they need to mix it up without it getting ugly.
David Greene, the view from the Clinton campaign on that?
She wants to paint Barack Obama as a novice who doesn't have the experience to be president without appearing to tear him down.
Because as you heard from Don, I mean so many people are excited about him, coming out to see him at these events.

Now, in a state like New Hampshire, you know, Barack Obama got the huge crowds and the interest, but Hillary Clinton was able to make the argument that she's the more seasoned public policy maker, and she won that state.
And I think that's the challenge she faces tonight in this debate and in the next few days.
NPR's David Greene and Don Gonyea.
Gentlemen, thank you.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Cohen.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Late Christmas afternoon in San Francisco at the city zoo, a tiger escaped its enclosure, attacked a visitor and killed him.
The 300-pound Siberian tiger also mauled two other men.
Then, four San Francisco police officers, searching for the tiger, found it outside a zoo cafe.
And when it charged them, they shot and killed it.
A police spokesperson described the scene for reporters.
As the officers moved even closer, the tiger focused its attention on the officers.
It started coming toward the officers.
That's when the officers fired.
Last year, that same tiger, Tatiana, reached through her cage's bars and injured a female zookeeper.
We're joined now by Ed Hansen, executive director of the American Association of Zookeepers.
Welcome to the program.
